instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .

threads.title: 820 3476 no green light no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
hello
820 3476 no dammage liquid
I dont have <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> on this board.
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> 16.6v

i have short on <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> pin 2
resistance pin 2 <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> 42.6 [COLOR=#545454][FONT=arial]Î©[/FONT][/COLOR]

Can u guys try help me figure out?

Thank you

threads.title: 820 3476 no green light no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Voltage on pin 6 and Pin 8 on <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>.

Diodemode reading on L7095.

threads.title: 820 3476 no green light no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
pin 6 and Pin 8 on [URL="https://store.rossmanngroup.com/a1-lt3470a.html"]<CHIP>U7090</CHIP>[/URL].   =   14.31v
Diodemode reading on L7095. = .027v

threads.title: 820 3476 no green light no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
So its not a dead short. I doubt injecting 3V into this rail will find the fault, but you could try as a LAST resort. Its time to examine the board for corrosion,

Was this liquid damage ?

threads.title: 820 3476 no green light no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
board for corrosion on <RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7094</CAPACITOR> and l7095
no dammage liquid .
When i inject 3.4volt on pin 2 l7095 = smc burn

threads.title: 820 3476 no green light no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Well that's shitty luck then. You'll need a donor SMC.

threads.title: 820 3476 no green light no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: First solve the issue why the SMC fried, check the 3V42 regulator for corrosion.

threads.title: 820 3476 no green light no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>

ahh good news, where is 3v42 regulator ?

thanks

threads.title: 820 3476 no green light no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: 820 3476 no green light no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The SMC is dead, it died for a reason. First fix the reason why it died, then replace the SMC.

threads.title: 820 3476 no green light no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You are probably and simply still having a partial short somewhere on the line.
While you were replacing <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> and smc (after removing old chip and before putting new one) did the short went away?
Is the new esmc still burning?

threads.title: 820 3476 no green light no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: SMC is shorted, replace it with one from identical donor board.
